article.title: Differential Distributions for t-channel Single Top-Quark Production and Decay at Next-to-Next-to-Leading Order in QCD

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 7 illustrate in relation to NNLO corrections from the heavy-quark line for the total inclusive cross section of single top-quark production at 13 TeV?
choices: The cancellation of different partonic channel contributions at NNLO.
The convergence of the total contribution as the cut-off parameter (τh,cut) decreases.
The stability of individual contributions (σ(2)VV, σ(2)RV, σ(2)RR) with varying cut-off values.
The impact of different PDF choices on the NNLO corrections.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 8 shows the cut-off dependence of different partonic channel contributions at NNLO from the heavy-quark line. What does this figure reveal about the power corrections at large τh,cut values (around 10^-1)?
choices: Power corrections are negligible for all partonic channels.
Power corrections from different channels cancel each other out, resulting in a small overall power correction.
The gluon channel exhibits the most significant power corrections.
The b-quark channel is insensitive to the variation of the cut-off parameter.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 9 demonstrates the NNLO corrections from the heavy-quark line for two differential distributions. What can be concluded from the agreement of the results at small cut-off values?
choices: The statistical uncertainties from numerical integration are negligible.
The power corrections are significant and must be accounted for.
The phase space slicing method is reliable and produces consistent results.
The choice of the cut-off parameter does not affect the NNLO corrections.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 11 presents the NNLO correction from top-quark decay on the fiducial cross section as a function of the cut-off. What issue does the incomplete cancellation of cut-off dependence with the naive flavor assignment indicate?
choices: Large statistical uncertainties from Monte Carlo integration.
Infrared problems with the naive flavor-jet algorithm.
Ambiguity in separating t-channel and s-channel contributions.
